ToOn Meeting, legally aCarned, and holden in

 Warren October 2Sd, 1925.

 Voted, That all Horned Cattle, (except two from a family,) and all Horses, Asses, Mules, and Sheep, shall he restrained from going at large on the Common or Highway, in said town of Warren the year ensuing. And if any Horses, Mules and Sheep shall be found running at large, on the Common or High way m said town the ensuing year, or more Horned Cattle than two from family, and they with the mark of the owner on the ear, any person shall have right to impound them in the same manner as is provided by law for the impounding of Horses, Cattle, Mules and Sheep, breaking into enclosures; 2 4S

 Attest. GEORGE STARR, I'o,cn Clerk.
NOTICE.

A COURSE of Medical Instruction will -IA be delivered at the Lecture Room, six doors west of the Court House. in west-street, the ensuing season. The introductory Lee ture will be given on Tuesday, the 10th of April A. D. 1927. Law as well as Medical Students, or other gentlemen desrous of hearing course of Medical Instruction. are respectfully requested to attend. Dr. Abbe will compence his Lecture at 12 o'clock M. Dr. Russell precisely at ,. Mir. Brace will begin his Course atthe commencement of his next term, being the 16th day of May next.

 JOHN w. RUSSELL, NJ. D.

 Litchield, April 8, 1927. 42
NOTICE.

WHEREAS, LAVINA WOODRUFF w of Litchfeld, in said County, has brought her petition to this Court against her husband Salmon Woodruff, now residing in parts to her unknown, therein stating, among other things, that the said Salmon, at said Litchfeld, on or about the first day of July 1923, wilfuIly deserted her, and ever since has continued, and still continues, his desertion, residing out of this state, in the total neglect of all the duties of the marriage covenant, on his part, to be performed, and praying for a bill of divorce from the said Salmon, as her petition on file, dated the 5th day of Februa- ry 1927.

 Ordered by this Court that said petition be continued to the next Term of this Court, to be holden at Litchield, within and for said County, on the third Tuesday of August next and that the pendency of said petition, and a copy of this order, be published six weeks successively, according to the statute in such case provided, in paper printed in Litchfeld, called the Litchfeid County Post, and in a pa per printed in New-Haven, called the Colum- bian Register, which shall be sufficient notice to the said Salmon to appear and defend in said petition.

 By the Court,

 F. WOLCOTT, Clerk. A true Copy. 6w4S

 FREDERICK wOLCOTT, Clerk.

{ LITCHFlELD COUNTY, ss.

 } Superior Court, Feb. Term 1927.

TNO be sold at Auction at the house lately

 occupied by David Soper, late of Tor ringford, deceased, on Monday the 18th day of April next, at o'clock P. M. unless pre- viously disposed of, Horse, Oxen, Cows and other Cattle, various kinds of Farming utensils, such as Cart, Ploughs, Chains, Wag- gon, Harness. and the like, together with Beds and Bed-furniture, Wearing Apparel, Cider and the Barrels, and all the personal estate lately belonging to the said deceased, by

 SAMUEL WOODWARD, Erec'r.

 Torringford, March 26, 1S27. 42
AUCTION.

TTPON the Petition of POLLY M. O ROOT, of Canaan, in said district, showing to this Court that she is guardian of Adeline Root, Oliver P. Root, and Sarteal Root, allof Canaan, minors that said minors are owners as tenants in common of an undi- vided share in a certain piece of land with 6 store and barn thereon standing, situated a. bout ten rods south of the meeting house, in Canaan aforesaid, Praying for liberty to sell the same as her petition on file dated March 27, 1897. Whereupon the Court doth adjourn the consideration ofsaid petition until the 18th day of June 1927, at the Probate Office in Salisbury in said district, at oclsck in the forenoon, and doth order that said Guardian give public Notice thereof by publishing this order in Newspaper printed in Litchfield three weeks successively, at least six weeks before the said 18th day of June 1927.

 A copy ofRecord,

 AZ Attest, SAMUEL CHURCH, Judge.
COURT OF PROBATE, ss. } District of Sharon, March 27. 1897. {

Ispent the afternoon on Friday, in com pany with MT. c. Hollock, and the whole day on Saturday, in visiting individuals and families, in different parts ofthe city, for the purpose ofascertaining, whether Dr. Cham bers' medicine for the cure of intemperance is eficacious. As the subject is one of much interest, I am willing to take the re- sponsibility of stating the evidence, which has been presented.

 I'D. w. of the firm of R. T. & w. a esnfleman of great responsibility, with

From Me Boston Recorder & Telegraph.

 CURE FOR INTEMPERANCF.

WYE the subscribers having been appoin- w ted Commissioners by the Hon. Su- perior Court holden at MiddIetown, in and for the County of MiddIesex, on inc 4th Tues day of Feb. 1927, on the estate of

 HORACE RANNEY,

 of fMiddletown, an insolyent debtor. to receive, examine and adjust the several debts due and owing by the said Horace Ranney, do here by give notice to the creditors of the said in- solvent debtor that they will meet at the house. of Zenas Edwards, in the Upper houses, on the first day of June, and on the first day of September, 1927 for the purpose aforesaid.

 JOSIAH SAVAGE, , Conamis-

 ZENAS EDWARDS, } sioners. Mddletown, March 14, 1927. 42
NOTICE.

WHEREAS my wife Mary Ann has left w my bed and board without any just provication This is to forbid all persons Rar boring or trusting her on my account, as I shall pay no debts of her contracting after this date.

 DAVID ROGERS, Jr. Washington, April g, 1897. 4s
NOTICE.

 d0ted M1Tch 30, 1927.

 The Lord is with us, of truth. Such a time in PttS6eld was never known. The Lord is carrying on his own work. 1t IS now about four weeks since the revlVal commenced. We have had three Inquiry Meetings. At the first there were 30 In- uuirers,-at the second 1OO,-at the third 400: besides 15O who were rejoicing ln hope. Opposition is not known. Every man stands in astonishment x says, " It IS the work of God" Some of cur boldest sinners have been converted by strong arm and large portion of our most in- teresting youth are among those who have either submitted, or are convicted. The prayers of Christians are, that 0N may be brought to the feet of Jesus, and feel the redeeming influence of his blood.

 There appears to be divine influence on the whole community. Even the air and the face of nature wear solemnlty, and our busy village has the appearance of the Sabbath.-Powerful revivals are at this time experienced in Richmond, Lenox, Lee, Otis, Beckett, Stockbridge, Williams town, and considerable attention in Great Darlington, Sheffield, Egremont, and New Marlborough. Also great attention in New Lebanon, Canaan, and Austerlitz, on the neighboring borders of New York. Sure ly this is good day for the church, for her light is come.

 RENTALS IN BERKSHIRE CouNTY.-A clergyman in Berkshire County writes thus to his friend in this city :-" With respect to the revival in this County, I have only time to say, that it far exceeds whatever has been known here before. Almost the whole County is moved. In Williams town, where the work has just commenced, it is said that almost every individual, both in College and town, is anxious or rejoi- cling. In Pittsfeld, the work is glorious. It was stated at our Sabbath prayer-meet- ing last Lords day, that 18O or more were indulging hope, and that 200 were pres ent at one Inquiry Meeting. In Lenox the number of conversions is about 20 a week. In Lee more than 200 are rejoi- cing in hope. At meeting there last week for young converts, those who dated their hope within the week preceding, were requested to rise: the number who rose was 40. Richmond and Stockbridge compare with Lenox: Sheffield and Egre- mont, with this town; "a few hoping, few inquiring. In Tyringham and the north part of New Marlborough, the state of re- ligion is very interesting.-In Williams town, Pitts6eld, New Marlborough and Tyringham, the work commenced only four or five weeks since. In Canaan, Green River, Spencertown and New Lebanon, in New York, the revival is not less anima- ting than in this County.-Something ve- ry interesting is apparent in the north part of Litchield County, Conn. A constant intercourse is kept up between the breth- ren by weekly conference, held in rota- tion at the several towns, and attended by delegates from the various churches. In all the towns, have mentioned, except New Lebanon, these conferences have been held ;-and in several more. A great bles- 'fing has invariabiy followed.

 RENTALS IN GEoRGIA.-A gentleman of responsibility, who has just arrived in this city from Athens, Geo. states that the revival in the College at that place, has re- suited in the hopeful conversion of about 90 students many of whom are from the most respectable families in the State, and some sustain high rank as scholars. This revival has already been noticed as exten- ding to Millegeville, and to the Legislature there assembled. Our informant states that four representatives from one County give evidence of true conversion and that two or three of them have united with the church. A work of grace appears to have commenced in Augusta, St. Mary's, Lib- erty County, and Savannah.

 LEBANON, CoNN.-A letter from gen. tleman in Lebanon, Conn. to a person in this city, dated April 1st 1927, says, |" We have revival of religion here which com menced the first of January. The number of converts is more than thirty principal lyyouth. ."-I6.

 REVIVAL IN PsRTLAND.-By a letter from pious individual in Portland, Me. dated March 29th, 1927, it appears that an interesting work of grace is going forward in that place, among the Congregational. ists. Baptists and Methodists. The num- Der now inquiring what they must do to be saved, the writer states to be not less than 500: and more than 100 indulge hope that their sins are washed away in the ato- ming blood of Jesus. The work appears to be thorough, and is advancing. Happy 1NRNUH af hn As
~Fmm the ". r. Observer. REVIVAL IN PITTSFIELD.

IN the road leading to Bradley's-Ville, a A POCKET-BOOK, containing small sum of money, and some papers of value to the owner, who may have the same by pro- wing property, and paying charges. Enquire at this office.

 Litchfeld, April g, 1927. 46
FOUND

' told me, that he had a man in his employ ment, 50 years ofage, who had been addict ed to intemperance many years, who ex- pressed Willingness 10 take any thing but poison to cure him. MT. w. procured some of the medicine and administered it few times, in consequence of which the old man has lost all thirst for spirituous liquors and appears like another man. He says, it cost him $50 year to get drunk, and now he does not love strong drink, and therefore he infers that he may yet rise in the world. This case is of two or three weeks contln- uance only.

 Mir. s. a respectable mechanic, well known here, and highly esteemed by many of our acquaintance, says, that he has young friend, who was subject to fits of ln- toxication, once in two or three weeks. He took the medicine or z weeks ago, and has lost all hankering for spirituous liquors. MT. s. and MT. w both express considera- ble confidence in the efficacy of the remedy.

 The Editor of the Chr. Advocate, shew- ed me two letters, written by persons in this city, with liberty to publish them, declaring that they had been cured by the use of this medicine. Er. B. from these letters, and from other testimony which has been pre- sented to him, has felt himself justified in writing an article in his paper in favor of the medicine.

 MT. H. as you know the editor of the Observer, has expressed an opinion from evidence obtained some weeks since, that the medicine was valuable. He has since, devoted more time to the examination of witnesses, the effect of which is to confirm the opinion already expressed.

 MT. N. venerable man, and one of the officers of the N. Y. Bible Society, has known many cases in which it has been administered, and his confidence in its etfl- cacy. He mentions two or three interesting and striking cases of cure.

 Mr. s. an old man, whom l saw, says he was ten years addicted tointemperance. He took the medicine or 6 weeks since, in consquence of which he has lost all hanker- ing for spirituous liquors. His employer gentleman of responsibility, confirms this and says he dismissed this man from his service before he took the medi- cine and has restored him since. saw both the individuals here spoken of.

 MT. K. an industrious mechanic, whom | saw, says his brother in law, youth of 19 years, had become curse to himself, & his friends, and had become so sottish, as to make it necessary to take him to the hospit- aL The physician at the hospital, said he could not have lived a fortnight, in the con- tinuance of such excess. This young man took the medicine weeks ago, in conse- quence of which he has. lost his thirst for spirituous liquor, and cannot be tempted to touch it His brother in law can use no lan- guage strong enough to express his conf- dence in the efficacy and value of this rem edy.

 MT. D. mechanic in the same neighbor- hood took the medicine about one week since, having been previously as we learnt from himself and wife very incorporate, and now he has no relish for spirituous li- quors. There were great indications Ofjoy and gratitude in the countenance and ex- pression of these people.

 P. K. took the medicine about the same time with D. He had been in the habit of drinking 15 or 16 glasses day, and in his last fit itofintoxicatian, he was drunk days. His cups were the first thing in the morning and the last at night; for the last or years he has been very much abandoned. His dreadful thirst for spirituous liquors is quenched, and he says he is willing to pro- claim to the world the benefit he has receiv- ed from Dr. Chambers.

 Mir. A. young man 30 years of age, has been dreadfully incorporate l5 years. His father, who is now dead twas the same, and brought up his son in his own habits. This young man has been twice lunantic {; three times brought to- the gates of death by fits; ten times committed to the watch house; and repeatedly brought home drunk to his mother who is widow, all in con- sequence of intemperance. He took the medicine seven weeks ago last Friday, and continued to take it till the Tuesday fol- lowing and he has had no desire for spir- itous liquors since. The facts in this case we collect from his mother, his employer and himself. have seld dom seen more greatful and happy woman than his mother.

 There are other cases; but have not time or space to state them.

 Dr. Chambers address, is Rutgers Med- ical College, Duane-street. The medi- cine is in phials at $5, each, with directions for using or in powders. which may be

LITCHFIELD COUNTY,

 Superior Court, Feb. Term, 1727. TTPON the Petition of DENSEA SIM O ONS of Colebrook, in said County, praying for Divorce from her husband JAMES SIMONS, for wilful deserton and absence from her, for more than three years with total neglect of duty-dated the 7th of Feb. A. D. l827-

 Ordered. that said petition be continued to the session of this Court to be held at Litch- field. in and for the county of Litchfeld. on the Sd Tuesday of August. A. D. 1827,---and that the publication of this order six weeks s,uccessively immediately after the rising of this Court, in the Newspaper printed in L.tch- held, called the Litch6eld County Post. and m the Newspaper printed in Hartford, called the Times & Hartford Advertiser shall be sufficient notice to the said James Simons of the pendency thereof.

 F. WOLCOTT, Clerk. - A true copy,

 FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Clerk.
L1TCHFIELD COUNTY,

OLIVE BEEBE, } LlTCHFIELD COUNTY,

 vs Superior Court, February ABrJAH BEEBE. Term, 1927.

 WHEREAS said OLIVE brought her W Petition to this Court, praying for Bill of Divorce against the said ABIJAH for his wilful dissertion. and total neglect of his duty; which Petition is continued to the next Term of the Superior Court, te be holden at Litchfeld,in and for the County of Litchfeld, on the Sd Tuesday of August next, when and where the said Abijah is notified to appear and show reasons if any he have, why the prayer of said Petition should not be granted.

 By order of Court,

 S76w FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Clerk.

Remaining in the POst-06fce Gt LitchfeId

 April 1St, 1897.
LIST OF LETTERS,

Duel.-The Vieksburg. Miss. paper of Feb. 18th, says:-

 "The Steamboat Rob Roy, which arrived here on Sunday last from New Orleans, brought us intelligence of the death of Judge Stockton. in duel. The meeting took place at New Orleans on Sunday the 4th inst in consequence of dispute which occurred at the Columbia Springs. We learn that Judge Stockton, previous to gOiug upon the ground, wrote letter. in which he heacknowledg ged that he had been the aggressOr, and expressed his determination not to return the fire of his an- tagonist."

WYE the subscribers having been appoin- w ted Commissioners by the Hon. Su- perior Court holden at MiddIetown, in and for the County of MiddIesex, on inc 4th Tues day of Feb. 1927, on the estate of

 HORACE RANNEY,

 of fMiddletown, an insolyent debtor. to receive, examine and adjust the several debts due and owing by the said Horace Ranney, do here by give notice to the creditors of the said in- solvent debtor that they will meet at the house. of Zenas Edwards, in the Upper houses, on the first day of June, and on the first day of September, 1927 for the purpose aforesaid.

 JOSIAH SAVAGE, , Conamis-

 ZENAS EDWARDS, } sioners. Mddletown, March 14, 1927. 42

WHEREAS my wife Mary Ann has left w my bed and board without any just provication This is to forbid all persons Rar boring or trusting her on my account, as I shall pay no debts of her contracting after this date.

 DAVID ROGERS, Jr. Washington, April g, 1897. 4s

full articles.headline: ~Fmm the ". r. Observer. REVIVAL IN PITTSFIELD.
full articles.article:
E tLESIcNGS L1SSSS' " t'" 7 SS''NS wv wv

 d0ted M1Tch 30, 1927.

 The Lord is with us, of truth. Such a time in PttS6eld was never known. The Lord is carrying on his own work. 1t IS now about four weeks since the revlVal commenced. We have had three Inquiry Meetings. At the first there were 30 In- uuirers,-at the second 1OO,-at the third 400: besides 15O who were rejoicing ln hope. Opposition is not known. Every man stands in astonishment x says, " It IS the work of God" Some of cur boldest sinners have been converted by strong arm and large portion of our most in- teresting youth are among those who have either submitted, or are convicted. The prayers of Christians are, that 0N may be brought to the feet of Jesus, and feel the redeeming influence of his blood.

 There appears to be divine influence on the whole community. Even the air and the face of nature wear solemnlty, and our busy village has the appearance of the Sabbath.-Powerful revivals are at this time experienced in Richmond, Lenox, Lee, Otis, Beckett, Stockbridge, Williams town, and considerable attention in Great Darlington, Sheffield, Egremont, and New Marlborough. Also great attention in New Lebanon, Canaan, and Austerlitz, on the neighboring borders of New York. Sure ly this is good day for the church, for her light is come.

 RENTALS IN BERKSHIRE CouNTY.-A clergyman in Berkshire County writes thus to his friend in this city :-" With respect to the revival in this County, I have only time to say, that it far exceeds whatever has been known here before. Almost the whole County is moved. In Williams town, where the work has just commenced, it is said that almost every individual, both in College and town, is anxious or rejoi- cling. In Pittsfeld, the work is glorious. It was stated at our Sabbath prayer-meet- ing last Lords day, that 18O or more were indulging hope, and that 200 were pres ent at one Inquiry Meeting. In Lenox the number of conversions is about 20 a week. In Lee more than 200 are rejoi- cing in hope. At meeting there last week for young converts, those who dated their hope within the week preceding, were requested to rise: the number who rose was 40. Richmond and Stockbridge compare with Lenox: Sheffield and Egre- mont, with this town; "a few hoping, few inquiring. In Tyringham and the north part of New Marlborough, the state of re- ligion is very interesting.-In Williams town, Pitts6eld, New Marlborough and Tyringham, the work commenced only four or five weeks since. In Canaan, Green River, Spencertown and New Lebanon, in New York, the revival is not less anima- ting than in this County.-Something ve- ry interesting is apparent in the north part of Litchield County, Conn. A constant intercourse is kept up between the breth- ren by weekly conference, held in rota- tion at the several towns, and attended by delegates from the various churches. In all the towns, have mentioned, except New Lebanon, these conferences have been held ;-and in several more. A great bles- 'fing has invariabiy followed.

 RENTALS IN GEoRGIA.-A gentleman of responsibility, who has just arrived in this city from Athens, Geo. states that the revival in the College at that place, has re- suited in the hopeful conversion of about 90 students many of whom are from the most respectable families in the State, and some sustain high rank as scholars. This revival has already been noticed as exten- ding to Millegeville, and to the Legislature there assembled. Our informant states that four representatives from one County give evidence of true conversion and that two or three of them have united with the church. A work of grace appears to have commenced in Augusta, St. Mary's, Lib- erty County, and Savannah.

 LEBANON, CoNN.-A letter from gen. tleman in Lebanon, Conn. to a person in this city, dated April 1st 1927, says, |" We have revival of religion here which com menced the first of January. The number of converts is more than thirty principal lyyouth. ."-I6.

 REVIVAL IN PsRTLAND.-By a letter from pious individual in Portland, Me. dated March 29th, 1927, it appears that an interesting work of grace is going forward in that place, among the Congregational. ists. Baptists and Methodists. The num- Der now inquiring what they must do to be saved, the writer states to be not less than 500: and more than 100 indulge hope that their sins are washed away in the ato- ming blood of Jesus. The work appears to be thorough, and is advancing. Happy 1NRNUH af hn As

full articles.headline: FOUND
full articles.article:
IN the road leading to Bradley's-Ville, a A POCKET-BOOK, containing small sum of money, and some papers of value to the owner, who may have the same by pro- wing property, and paying charges. Enquire at this office.

 Litchfeld, April g, 1927. 46

' told me, that he had a man in his employ ment, 50 years ofage, who had been addict ed to intemperance many years, who ex- pressed Willingness 10 take any thing but poison to cure him. MT. w. procured some of the medicine and administered it few times, in consequence of which the old man has lost all thirst for spirituous liquors and appears like another man. He says, it cost him $50 year to get drunk, and now he does not love strong drink, and therefore he infers that he may yet rise in the world. This case is of two or three weeks contln- uance only.

 Mir. s. a respectable mechanic, well known here, and highly esteemed by many of our acquaintance, says, that he has young friend, who was subject to fits of ln- toxication, once in two or three weeks. He took the medicine or z weeks ago, and has lost all hankering for spirituous liquors. MT. s. and MT. w both express considera- ble confidence in the efficacy of the remedy.

 The Editor of the Chr. Advocate, shew- ed me two letters, written by persons in this city, with liberty to publish them, declaring that they had been cured by the use of this medicine. Er. B. from these letters, and from other testimony which has been pre- sented to him, has felt himself justified in writing an article in his paper in favor of the medicine.

 MT. H. as you know the editor of the Observer, has expressed an opinion from evidence obtained some weeks since, that the medicine was valuable. He has since, devoted more time to the examination of witnesses, the effect of which is to confirm the opinion already expressed.

 MT. N. venerable man, and one of the officers of the N. Y. Bible Society, has known many cases in which it has been administered, and his confidence in its etfl- cacy. He mentions two or three interesting and striking cases of cure.

 Mr. s. an old man, whom l saw, says he was ten years addicted tointemperance. He took the medicine or 6 weeks since, in consquence of which he has lost all hanker- ing for spirituous liquors. His employer gentleman of responsibility, confirms this and says he dismissed this man from his service before he took the medi- cine and has restored him since. saw both the individuals here spoken of.

 MT. K. an industrious mechanic, whom | saw, says his brother in law, youth of 19 years, had become curse to himself, & his friends, and had become so sottish, as to make it necessary to take him to the hospit- aL The physician at the hospital, said he could not have lived a fortnight, in the con- tinuance of such excess. This young man took the medicine weeks ago, in conse- quence of which he has. lost his thirst for spirituous liquor, and cannot be tempted to touch it His brother in law can use no lan- guage strong enough to express his conf- dence in the efficacy and value of this rem edy.

 MT. D. mechanic in the same neighbor- hood took the medicine about one week since, having been previously as we learnt from himself and wife very incorporate, and now he has no relish for spirituous li- quors. There were great indications Ofjoy and gratitude in the countenance and ex- pression of these people.

 P. K. took the medicine about the same time with D. He had been in the habit of drinking 15 or 16 glasses day, and in his last fit itofintoxicatian, he was drunk days. His cups were the first thing in the morning and the last at night; for the last or years he has been very much abandoned. His dreadful thirst for spirituous liquors is quenched, and he says he is willing to pro- claim to the world the benefit he has receiv- ed from Dr. Chambers.

 Mir. A. young man 30 years of age, has been dreadfully incorporate l5 years. His father, who is now dead twas the same, and brought up his son in his own habits. This young man has been twice lunantic {; three times brought to- the gates of death by fits; ten times committed to the watch house; and repeatedly brought home drunk to his mother who is widow, all in con- sequence of intemperance. He took the medicine seven weeks ago last Friday, and continued to take it till the Tuesday fol- lowing and he has had no desire for spir- itous liquors since. The facts in this case we collect from his mother, his employer and himself. have seld dom seen more greatful and happy woman than his mother.

 There are other cases; but have not time or space to state them.

 Dr. Chambers address, is Rutgers Med- ical College, Duane-street. The medi- cine is in phials at $5, each, with directions for using or in powders. which may be

full articles.headline: L1TCHFIELD COUNTY,
full articles.article:
LITCHFIELD COUNTY,

 Superior Court, Feb. Term, 1727. TTPON the Petition of DENSEA SIM O ONS of Colebrook, in said County, praying for Divorce from her husband JAMES SIMONS, for wilful deserton and absence from her, for more than three years with total neglect of duty-dated the 7th of Feb. A. D. l827-

 Ordered. that said petition be continued to the session of this Court to be held at Litch- field. in and for the county of Litchfeld. on the Sd Tuesday of August. A. D. 1827,---and that the publication of this order six weeks s,uccessively immediately after the rising of this Court, in the Newspaper printed in L.tch- held, called the Litch6eld County Post. and m the Newspaper printed in Hartford, called the Times & Hartford Advertiser shall be sufficient notice to the said James Simons of the pendency thereof.

 F. WOLCOTT, Clerk. - A true copy,

 FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Clerk.

OLIVE BEEBE, } LlTCHFIELD COUNTY,

 vs Superior Court, February ABrJAH BEEBE. Term, 1927.

 WHEREAS said OLIVE brought her W Petition to this Court, praying for Bill of Divorce against the said ABIJAH for his wilful dissertion. and total neglect of his duty; which Petition is continued to the next Term of the Superior Court, te be holden at Litchfeld,in and for the County of Litchfeld, on the Sd Tuesday of August next, when and where the said Abijah is notified to appear and show reasons if any he have, why the prayer of said Petition should not be granted.

 By order of Court,

 S76w FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Clerk.

 April 1St, 1897.

Duel.-The Vieksburg. Miss. paper of Feb. 18th, says:-

 "The Steamboat Rob Roy, which arrived here on Sunday last from New Orleans, brought us intelligence of the death of Judge Stockton. in duel. The meeting took place at New Orleans on Sunday the 4th inst in consequence of dispute which occurred at the Columbia Springs. We learn that Judge Stockton, previous to gOiug upon the ground, wrote letter. in which he heacknowledg ged that he had been the aggressOr, and expressed his determination not to return the fire of his an- tagonist."
